short_history_of_the_islands: Zanzibar consists of two big sister Islands of Unguja and Pemba situated in the Indian Ocean with more than fifty “50” small Islets. Unguja is unique coral island covers the land area of 1464sq km whereby Pemba is 2332sq km. It is located at 35km off coast Mainland, between 39 degrees longitude and 6 degrees latitude south of equator. Zanzibar was originally the independent Country and remained so until April , 1964 when it was united with Tanganyika to form a United Republic Of Tanzania .how ever Zanzibar has its Government , a House Of Representative , and its certain degree of autonomy within the United Republic Of Tanzania. The Island`s history goes beyond many centuries ago. During the Age of Exploration ,in 1498 the Portuguese Empire was the first European power to gained control of Zanzibar, and kept it for more than 200 years until in 1698 Zanzibar fell under the control of the Sultanate of Oman and then in the early 19 th century the Sultan of Oman from the Al busaid tried moved his capital city to Zanzibar officially and permanently . During the reign of the Sultan , Spice cultivation was introduced and developed especially the Clove trees and among other trade Slavery was also introduced and got Zanzibar as it strategically key meeting point from all the East African region. The cosmopolitan Zanzibar becomes the most important town in East and Central Africa for its unique location and culture of her people.

geography: Zanzibar Islands have a total 2,332 square kilometers ,other Island that makes up Zanzibar for Unguja including Tumbatu island which lies at northeast of Unguja Islands , Chumbe Island which is very famous for its biodiversity and coral reefs, Mnemba island commonly known as the best site for Diving and Changuu also very known Prison Island a good site for Snorkeling and presence for endanger Tortoises , also Misali island for Pemba. Pemba Islands is the second largest Island of the archipelago famous known as “ Jazira Al-Khudra” by Arabic mariners which means “ the Green Island”. It is more famous for its huge productivity of cloves and its channels offer some of the best diving experiences in East Africa.

climate: Zanzibar like many other parts of the World has four common types of Climate . Heavy Rain season starts from March to May , Short rains in November while Cold and Dry periods are experienced amid June to October .The average temperature is 25 Centigrade , August is the Coolest month of the year . However the cold period in Zanzibar is very different compare to what people from far east or Western Countries do experience , it may be correct to say to them this will be not a Cold but summer

population: From the recent sensor taken in 2010 Zanzibar was estimated to have 1.5 milion people, while the official first language is Kiswahili, and other languages used here English and Arabic.

religion: Zanzibar is now believed to have a dense population of 1.5 milion people, while some recent researches have shown 96.32 % of that are Islam religion, followed by Hindus and others 1.5% Catholic and Anglican 2.05% Lutheran 0.05%, Evangelicals  0.08%  , of all people.But it is true that the majority numbers of Christians in Zanzibar Islands are from Tanzania mainland who has been moving here for different reasons as there are those who came here under the job transfer as Civil servants, others through business activities other but all in all Zanzibar is in Tanzania .

passport_and_visa: All travelers to Africa require a passport, valid for the duration of their tour or vacation in Tanzania. Entry points in Tanzania currently offering visa services on entry include the ports in Dar es Salaam and Zanzibar, international airports at Dar es Salaam, Zanzibar and Kilimanjaro airports and Sea ports, and also Namanga entry post on the road border between Tanzania and Kenya. Some nationalities do not require visas, so it is advisable to check with your local Tanzanian Embassy.

language_and_people: Kiswahili is the official and national language of Tanzania which obviously reflects the culture diversity of its birthplace , Zanzibar .The language is built up of some words which were borrowed from Indigenous bantu tribe languages , Arabic , Persian , English , the Indian languages , Kutchi , Gujarati , Portuguese and Germany . However English is widely spoken in towns and tourist resorts alongside Italian, French , Arabic and Spanish. If you only use a few Swahili words whilst you are in Tanzania you may make some local friend!

accomodation: Zanzibar offers different grades of hotels depending on your budget and interest; here you can find resorts, guests houses and Bungalows enough to give you perfect option to find the one that suits your desire and budget. Almost many of the accommodation includes breakfast in their price. There are hotels /resorts which are at beach and other are just are inland situated and there are also categorized in grades of stars , from one to five stars.

public_holidays: Like many others places around the world , Zanzibar also have Public holidays which are constitutionally and lawfully recognized and are in categories as some are Public while others are religious and other are just tradionally known. For Christian , there is fist day of the new Year 1 st January , Good Friday and Easter Monday “ March /April and Christmas “ December 25 th and Boxing Day December 26 th . For Muslims public holidays are Eid – al-Hajj , Maulid , and Eid –al-Fitr are observed , dates vary from one year to another as their Calendar bases on lunar cycles of 29 to 30 days.Public holidays include national days among them , Zanzibar Revolution Day “ Independence Day “ which is celebrated from the midnight on January 12 th with noisy Guns salutes and blaring of ship horns at Forodhani water front , and Maisara ground . Also the Union Day which celebrates the union between Tanganyika and Zanzibar on 26 th , also Workers Day “ May 1 st , Industrial Day July 7 th , Farmer`s Day August 8 th and Tanganyika Independence Day. Zanzibar also recognizes the International Days.

security: Tanzania is a generally safe country but don't invite temptation. Keep your eyes on your belongings. Don't walk in the towns or cities at night - take a taxi. Don't carry cameras or large amounts of cash, beware of pickpockets and hawkers. Use hotel safety deposit boxes to safeguard valuables and obtain a receipt. Leave valuable jewelry at home.

communication: You can have an access of communication in many ways while in Zanzibar , for telephones you can get it from the hotel you are to stay , or you can buy your own Sim chip from local Mobile phone companies such as Zantel , Tigo , Vodacom , Airtel and now Halotel but remember to take you public ID for registration before you can access it. Many hotels offer free Wi-Fi where you can access internet from your own devices such as Smartphones , Tablets and Laptops , but if not then there are Internet Caffes at Zanzibar Old Post office where you can go and pay as you go.

money: Major foreign currencies - particularly US$ and Euros - and travellers cheques are accepted and are convertible at banks and bureau de changes in the main towns and tourist areas. Credit cards are not widely accepted and carry poor exchange rates. ATM facilities are available in Stone Town but may be unreliable and are not available elsewhere. Visitors may be expected to pay in foreign currency at game parks. Don't change money on the street.

medical: All visitors are required to present an International Yellow Fever Immunization Certificate upon arrival .Vaccination for typhoid , tetanus , diphtheria , polio , meningitis and hepatitis A are usually recommended. Although there is very little Malaria on Zanzibar, it is also advisable to take an anti-malarial precaution which means a suitable course of prophylactics should be started before departure or consult your doctor or Travel clinic while planning your trip. You are advised to cover up yourself after sunset and use mosquito repellent on exposed skin. Remember also HIV is a threat and precaution should be taken to ensure your safety. We advise also you take with you some anti-sun- burning lotion in case you expect to spend your time in the areas which are exposed to strong sunny like beaches. Visitors with specific medical needs should bring an extra supply of any prescribed medication, stored separately in case of loss or damage according the special requirement the particular medication is scientically required to be preserved . One last important thing to remember is medical facilities in Zanzibar are limited , therefore you are advised to have your comprehensive travel insurance to cover the unlikely event of serious accident or illness.

electric_current: The local current is 220 – 240 V AC 50Hz. Most electric plug sockets takes three pin British plugs , although some are wired for continental European plugs .There are still occasional power cuts in Zanzibar , and although these are becoming less but visitors are advised not to leave electrical appliances plugged in when not in use due to power surges , don’t also to bring with you an universal adaptor and a torch (flashlight).

etiquette: Because of religious and cultural traditions dress code is important, and men and women should dress appropriately when away from the beach, i.e. covering shoulders and legs to below the knees. Beachwear on the beach is fine, although nude or topless bathing is not tolerated. When in villages or in Stone Town wearing beachwear can (and does) cause offence. Try to wear loose-fitting, non-transparent clothing when in public. During the Muslim holy month of Ramadan where they are fasting , it is considered the height of bad manner to eat , drink or smoke in public so please we advise you to do everything possible to offend them and spend your time free and joyful without hurt anyone . However dates for Ramadan may change from year to year as Islamic calendar depends on the moon .

what_to_carry_with_you: Pack lightweight, washable clothes a sunhat, sunglasses and sunscreen. Long sleeves and trousers in light-colored fabrics help discourage insect bites. Shorts for women are acceptable (but not too short). Women should carry a wrap to cover legs in the village and towns as revealing clothes can cause offence but if staying at a hotel / Resort , bring your swimsuit along.Bring film and batteries for your camera with you. Protect your camera from dust and keep equipment and film spools cool. It is courteous to ask permission before photographing local people. Do not take photos or film at sensitive government sites including the State House, Seaport, Airport or Military sites. If uncertain, it is always better to ask.

tipping: Not obligatory, but a tip for exceptional service (max 10%) will be appreciated, $10-$25 per day for driver or tour guide is much appreciated.

shopping: The tourist areas including Stone town and Spice farm shops sell a wide range of souvenirs, jewelry and trinkets. Don't be afraid to haggle at roadside stalls (Your driver/ guide will advise you where to shop and on a reasonable price). The most popular souvenirs are wooden carvings, curios, and a famous love stone "Tanzanite", which are all widely sold at souvenir shops.
